Read (or listen as an audiobook) the book Knowledge and decisions by Thomas Sowell. It will change your life, and teach you how to think about this stuff. Everything that matters is our actions, and our actions are result from our decision, and our decision are result of our limited knowledge of the situation and a lot of incentives and constraints. If you ask people that know a lot on the things you know little you are kinda becoming a genus, at least desision wise. You cannot learn and know everything but you can ask people diferent people that knows. Just like Tywin Lanister from GOT what makes a good king - a good king is a wise king, one which ask people about the things he doesn't know.

Thanks for this. Needed help in choosing schools.

If you have too many options, find a way to filter down to 3 choices. Set those options aside and come back the next day if possible. It's mentioned in the video as her example, but not exactly why. Too many choices leads to something called 'overchoice'/'choice overload'/'too many options paralysis'. 3 is about the max you can fully compare against each other at once. The example case for this while I was in school was all about pasta sauce.

Quite frankly, humans are bad decision-makers with how many decisions we force ourselves or choose to make.

I'm sure everyone has heard this before, but let me repeat that in trying to master a skill you will get worse before you get better. It happens everywhere, and again we are horrible at pushing through unless sufficiently motivated. Many companies announce a strategy shift, stop the change while people are just starting to get the hang of the new strategy so are underdelivering, then either persist at that low point or reverse direction while declaring success. Again, humans can be really bad at this. You are not alone.

Just because I've decided to be "_that guy_" today, legally speaking Kenneth Lay (the former CEO of Enron) had his conviction overturned during the appeals process on a technicality. That technicality being that he died of a heart attack while his appeals were pending. When that happens, a defendant has their judgement vacated. Under the _law_, he died an innocent man. We all know what he did though.
